In May, the NAEB conducted a working conference on "Communication
Technology and the People Left Behind, " with primary concentration on rural
poverty. The first of a series which will explore the application of communication
technology to societal problems , this conference brought together sociologists,
educational broadcasters, educational administrators, and government officials
to develop awareness, techniques, and recommendations for approaches to deal
with the needs of the rural deprived.
Later, NAEB announced the formation of two national committees to examine
the role of educational broadcasting regarding programming and employment
practices for minority groups. Both committees will report their findings and
make recommendations to the NAEB Board of Directors, which will report to the
full NAEB membership.
ETV interests will be represented at meetings relating to these problems:
U. S. Community Relations Service Media Seminar, June 21-23,
Aspen, Colorado;
George Washington University Urban Problems Seminar, June 19-21,
Warrenton, Virginia;
NEA on May 6 conducted one-day conference in Washington on media
and the urban problems, as they relate to education.
Reports on these and other meetings will be sent to you as they are
compiled.
